body:
Hello there, I looked at your screenshot and you seemed to have configured everything properly.
Video2X should automatically output the video in the same format the input video is using, but I'm not sure why it's not working properly.

Could you please insert these lines in `video2x.py` just to debug the problem?

https://github.com/k4yt3x/video2x/blob/3d46e1a822236db1cb25f970ae1c8bf492334f1d/bin/video2x.py#L314

After line 314, change this:

```python
output_video = '{}\\{}'.format(args.output, input_video)
upscaler = Upscaler(input_video=os.path.join(args.input, input_video), output_video=output_video, method=args.method, waifu2x_settings=waifu2x_settings, ffmpeg_settings=ffmpeg_settings)

```

into this:

```python
output_video = '{}\\{}'.format(args.output, input_video)
 print(output_video)
breakpoint()
upscaler = Upscaler(input_video=os.path.join(args.input, input_video), output_video=output_video, method=args.method, waifu2x_settings=waifu2x_settings, ffmpeg_settings=ffmpeg_settings)
```

It should look something like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21986859/55429862-6e73a100-555a-11e9-9b2a-39d17628da55.png)

Then, run the script again using the command you provided above, and the script should stop shortly after execution. Take a screenshot of the output, and post it on here.
Ah weird, well I ran it https://imgur.com/a/zOvgI5e

I think you pasted the lines wrong.
Take a screenshot of the code.
Hmm https://imgur.com/a/HfXzTw3
line 316 and 317 should be indented. compare your code with my screenshot above
You're correct, lol just saw my bad

It skipped upscaling part and went to ffmpeg as it should, it then looped back and started to convert frames without stopping (just for future debugging purposes) https://imgur.com/a/bMS7zuf

Edit: The script doesn't stop after implementing that code https://imgur.com/a/Ce6panF

and after reverting back I still get an invalid code that showed in my image. Not to sure what I did wrong as the code matches.

It should not be skipping. It should pause before upscaling.
Your input is a folder right?

Ah okay, well it didn't pause for me so I must have done something wrong: inserted code, compile test, saved, cmd, same command as before. 

Yes, I dragged the file into the command prompt, it created the path (which is correct). https://imgur.com/a/o5BHGcN

Ok now I see what's going on.
If the input is the file, then the output should also be a file, not a folder.

Video2x is working as intended.

My "Display the full path in the title bar" was disabled - that should be included into the instructions to check so that someone doesn't have to specify the file type at the end because it will not auto recognize what you want.

If you're handling a single file, you'll have to specify both the input file name and the output file name.
If you're handling files in a folder, then all input file names will be copied, also the video codec.

Maybe I can add a function where if you don't specify the output file, it generates the file name and copies the input file format for you?

That would be a great function to add in to fool proof it on top of this, but also I think adding in the instructions a note about the "display full path" in windows and the output behavior - thank you for the timely responses.

I'll consider adding a function to check the path.
You're welcome.

I just thought about it, how would I perform the check though?
match "^\*.\*" ?

What I was thinking is if --> Input =/= Output (file type) follow path and get directory items as list, parse the end of the path and look for a name match in directory (File.Type), then output that type if found, else output a message to the user at least telling them for this specific situation what's wrong. Not a big deal anymore, but it's a feature haha.

> parse the end of the path and look for a name match in directory (File.Type), then output that type if found

Sorry I'm kinda confused. Maybe I didn't sleep enough.
Could you please give an example?

Haha sorry, I just got two ideas confused there, I don't want to waste more of your time though so don't worry about it if it still doesn't make sense or isn't feasible. Take this path for example:

python video2x.py -m gpu -r 4 -d waifu2x_converter -i C:\Users\Master\Documents\Input.mkv -o C:\Users\Master\StoreVideo\SubFolder   (notice missing name.mkv for output, this means SubFolder is a Folder)

Take path directory (C:\Users\Master\StoreVideo\SubFolder), Check directory is empty (dir C:\Users\Master\StoreVideo\SubFolder) else look for similar Name.Type so we don't create a conflict, Assume "SubFolder" = folder, Add onto the path InputName.mkv as the output file name.

New adjustments:
python video2x.py -m gpu -r 4 -d waifu2x_converter -i C:\Users\Master\Documents\Input.mkv -o C:\Users\Master\StoreVideo\SubFolder\InputName.mkv

I'm expecting input type to match output type, so I think what I'm going to do is:

```
if output is folder:
    warn user file IO mismatch
elif output does not match *.* (missing suffix):
    warn suffix needed
```
Ah yeah, that's way more simple than mine. Looks great to me! Thanks.
Implemented in the newest commit.
